Award.AwardTitle: Toward Soft Diamond: Molecular Modeling for the Engineering of Novel Super-tough Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Materials where molecular building blocks are purposely connected in very regular three-dimensional networks are the object of increasing interest. This interest stems in part from the ability to synthesize such materials via self-assembly methods. Depending on the building block used, widely varied materials could be synthesized. At one extreme, a single carbon atom as building block leads to diamond, the hardest materials found in nature. At the other extreme, a very long hydrocarbon chain as building block leads to very soft plastics. In between, building blocks of intermediate size and stiffness would lead to exciting new materials that combine some of the strength of diamond with the elasticity of rubbers. Our preliminary studies have revealed that networks made of two types of building blocks that differ in stiffness or chemical affinity would form rubbers that mimic the elastic response of super-tough natural materials such as the adhesive in abalone shells and spiders' silk. This study is complementary to experimental efforts by other groups. It will fill a gap in the need for computational models that help identify specific material configurations of interest. The research will hence provide guidelines for the design of super-tough "rubbery diamonds" that could become a new materials' paradigm. In the long term, this could impact a broad range of materials related industries. The work will also provide opportunities for the involvement of underrepresented groups in research and the development of educational materials.

Since the resistance to deformation in an elastomer composed of ordered and amorphous domains is associated with the free energy cost of rearranging those domains, it is postulated that the elastic properties of regular networks can be optimized by using building blocks that allow control of the free-energy barriers of the underlying order-disorder phase transitions (driven by deformation). Accordingly, the plan is to synergistically leverage the self-assembling properties of chains that are capable of forming entropy-driven liquid crystalline order (like semiflexible chains) and enthalpy-driven micro-segregated ordered phases (like block copolymers) to tune the non-linear elastic behavior of end-chain crosslinked networks with no or minimal defects. The aim is to modulate the height and number of free-energy barriers associated with a sawtooth elastic response. Molecular dynamics simulations will be used to investigate the effects on elastic behavior of different block copolymers (whose blocks differ in either enthalpic affinity or backbone flexibility) and of non-ideal architectures and defects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rubbery materials or elastomers consist of networks made of polymer chains and are the basis of numerous applications in use Today and for the foreseeable future. A key characteristic of elastomers is their ability to deform significantly when an external force is applied to them and yet are able to recover their original shape once the perturbing force ceases. In doing so, elastomers can absorb energy, a property quantified as toughness, which is the basis for applications involving shock absorbing and cushioning materials. This project dealt with the use of molecular modeling techniques to develop new classes of elastomers that would allow them to be super-stretchable and super-tough, by using molecular building blocks with a propensity to undergo well-defined microscopic rearrangements that release a ?hidden chain length? when the sample is deformed. The project leveraged the recent progress made in programmed self-assembled of molecular building blocks to approach the ability of nature to create highly precise molecular architectures. In particular, the sought-after materials have molecular architectures and properties which are interpolations between those or very strong, hard materials (like diamond ? the hardest known natural material) and very elastic, soft materials (like rubber bands). The key to such an extreme ability to tune mechanical properties is to interconnect polymer chains in very regular and periodic patterns ? a sort of ?nanoscale 3-dimensional fishnets? where individual threads are polymer chains.

Our simulations predict that our elastomers exhibit a force-extension curve with successive peaks or ?teeth?, which is similar to the pattern exhibited by other well-known ?super? strong natural materials such as spider silk, abalone shells, and muscle fibers. The force drop after each peak prevents the material from breaking at high forces, and the multiple peaks allows absorbing more energy, hence leading to high toughness and extensibility. This idea is illustrated in the accompanying figure 1. Our studies have elucidated several design principles to engineer such super-tough, super-stretchable elastomers, including how the target regular architectures are affected by the chemical reaction conditions, and how the mechanical properties of the material are affected by different molecular designs, polymer lengths, and external conditions like temperature and extent of deformation. Some of our studies have dealt with generic polymer models to obtain qualitative general trends of behavior while others dealt with chemistry specific materials to make specific quantitative predictions to compare against existing materials. Such new designs are now closer to reality thanks to newer experimental techniques available to polymer chemists. It is expected that these materials can be designed for use as artificial cartilage, extra-light weight vehicle parts, bulletproof vests, shock absorbers, and super strong fibers for garments and specialty applications.

The research was carried out primarily by a full-time research graduate student at any given time. One of these students, Endian Wang, graduated with a M. S. degree in 2016. A second student, Poornima Padmanabhan, also graduated with a Ph.D. also in 2016 and went on to become assistant Professor at Rochester Institute of Technology. The third student, Chris Nowak, recently graduated with a PhD and is set to join the Sandia National Laboratory.

Eight peer-reviewed papers have been published in top specialty journals with a ninth likely to be published later in the year. Besides publications, results of this research were also disseminated through half-a-dozen invited Departmental Seminars and oral presentations at National meetings (e.g., by the AIChE and APS), and international conferences (e.g., the CCP5 Annual General Meeting at Manchester UK on September 2018).

The main outreach activity entailed our participation in the 8th (2017) and 10th (2019) annual WOMEN (Women?s Outreach in Materials, Energy, and Nanobiotechnology) event for 10th grade girls that took place at Cornell. These day-long events aim to encourage girls from rural high schools to pursue careers in engineering. Our activity involved several simple experiments illustrating the making of simple polymers (like nylon and silly putty) to illustrate their extreme swelling properties (i.e., to absorb large amounts of water) and varying extents of stiffness. Students also selected among several colorful, software-generated pictures illustrating the microscopic ordering of materials, and then asked to provide a creative caption. The most popular picture and caption were used to create a print for T-shirts which were mailed to the participants as a wearable souvenir.
